TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {52854=Topics in United States History 1600-1900 (HIST 17A) OR, 71870=The approved Master's Thesis/Project format guide is the American Psychological Association (APA) - latest edition. Enrollment in CHDV 504 Project/Thesis course or CHDV 505 Culminating Experience: CHDV Exam require that the student file an Intent to Register form at least one full semester in advance of registration in these courses. The Intent to Register form must be signed by the student's faculty sponsor, and is due by March 15 for fall semester enrollment and by October 15 for spring semester enrollment. For students intending to complete a project or thesis, a petition must be approved prior to beginning the project or thesis. The petition requires approval from the thesis/project sponsor and from the Child Development Department Chair. Please see your list of deadlines or consult with a program advisor., 51671=United States History, 1607-1877, 85480=*May be fulfilled by enrollment in the equivalent course offered through another department in the College of Education. However, students are advised to enroll in the Child Development sections if possible., 52035=World Civilizations, Beginnings -1600}
textBeforeTable: A. Required Foundation Courses (12 units) Courses in parentheses are prerequisites. Units required for Major: 49-50 Minimum total units required for BA: 120 Requirements - Bachelor of Arts Degree - Child Development: Concentration - Early Development, Care, and Education (EDCE) In addition, the program has at its disposal an excellent selection of books and journals in the Library and many films, video and audio tapes, and other media to implement and support instruction. Students are given opportunities to observe and participate with children in a variety of settings in the community and on campus. Please contact the Department office for information about the service-learning, cooperative education, and other field-based experiences available. The quality of instruction and the varying educational and professional backgrounds of the faculty provide a program which meets the diverse demands of the many career options available in this field. The University's location in the State's capital city provides a variety of unique fieldwork, internship, cooperative learning, and part-time employment opportunities. Special Features Note: Child Development students should check the department Web site (http://edweb.csus.edu/chdv/) for updates to degree requirements and current issues related to child development. To plan for a timely graduation, students should meet with an advisor each semester. Students who wish to pursue an elementary school (multiple subjects) teaching credential should make an appointment with a child development faculty advisor in the Center for Teaching Majors
